title: HyFlux Superconducting Electric Motor
description: Case study focusing on the cryogenic heat exchanger for a superconducting electric machine.

payload.projectDescription: Cryogenic HX for a superconducting propulsion motor.

payload.content: A 20–40 passenger regional commuter aircraft using hybrid-electric propulsion with a superconducting propulsion motor. The cryogenic HX is part of the thermal management loop supporting HTS stator windings and power electronics.
Deliver 2 MW class motor with >97% efficiency; cryogenic loop COP ≥ 0.06; HX ΔT ≤ 3 K at design mass flow; TRL 6 by 2028; mass ≤ 25 kg; pressure drop ≤ 0.15 bar.

Compact plate-fin cryogenic heat exchanger integrated with HTS stator cold-plate. Working fluid: gaseous helium at 20–40 K. Additive manufactured fins, high-conductivity alloy, embedded temperature/pressure sensors with redundant channels.

Superconducting propulsion reduces conductor losses enabling higher power density. The HX is critical to maintain HTS operating temperature and protect against quench. Development targets manufacturability, icing/contamination tolerance, and maintainability.

Baseline architecture: single-loop He gas; turbocompressor + JT valve; HX effectiveness ≥ 0.9; 270 VDC bus to cryo-compressor; initial safety case addresses quench detection, venting, leak-before-burst, and DO-160 thermal/vibration.
